Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2009 03:28PM sadmom wrote: Kendall, your situation sounds much like my daughter.  She had a lumpectomy on Sept. 10, tumor was 1.8 cm., ER+PR+HER2-, no node involvement BUT vascular/lymphatic invasion.  She turned 31 on the date of her surgery.  The doctor said even though there was no evidence that the cancer had spread, with the vascular/lymphatic invasion it had the capability to do so.  Chemo was strongly recommended so she is having FAC 4x (3 down, 1 to go), 12 weeks of Taxol, then rads and 5 years of tamoxifen.  She tested negative for BRAC1 & 2.  I was diagnosed 20 years ago, had a lumpectomy and radiation, no node involvement.  No recurrences.  Same size tumor.  I hate that she has to undergo chemo, but she absolutely wanted to do everything she could to prevent this from ever coming back again.  And I feel very relieved about that.  She is doing well, lost her hair but not her amazing attitude and upbeat personality!  She does get nauseous but has never thrown up, is tired for 4-5 days after chemo and does not have the energy she did but overall she is pretty amazed at how well treatment has gone for her so far.  Has a job that she loves but puts in lots of hours, her supervisors and co-workers have been great.  She only misses a Friday and Monday every 3 weeks.  As a mom, even though I have been well for 20 years due to lots of prayers and good luck, I am so glad she is doing everything she can to get well and stay that way.
Posts.Title: just got sucky news Klawless9 sadmom

Posts.Content: May 10, 2010 12:18AM sadmom wrote: I had 34 lymph nodes removed 20 years ago and have not had any problems with lymphedema, yet anyway!  I'm 54.  I too do not have blood drawn on that arm or blood pressure taken, other than that I don't baby it at all.  I lift, garden without gloves sometimes etc.  I'm just plain lucky!  I do notice some tightness in that armpit and once in awhile an ache, but have never had any swelling in that arm.  Guess I should take better care of it just in case!
Posts.Title: Anyone NOT have lymphedemia from lymph removal?? khill Jenniferz

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2010 09:18PM sadmom wrote: Almost 21 years!  Diagnosed in Oct. of 1989 at age 34, had lumpectomy, radiation, tamox.  No recurrences, but unfortunately my daughter was diagnosed a year ago July at age 30. She was also Stage 1.  She was tested for BRAC 1 & 2, negative.  Go figure!
Posts.Title: How many years have you been a Survivor? IllinoisNancy Lou789

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2010 10:28AM sadmom wrote: I was 34, diagnosed in 1989, ERPR+, no node involvement, had  lumpectomy and radiation, been fine since.  Daughter diagnosed in July 09 at 30, ERPR+, HER2-, 0/2 nodes, lumpectomy, FAC 4x, now undergoing Taxol 12x and will have rads, tamox. She tested neg for BRAC genes.  I had a biopsy which was negative in late 1988 but 6 months later had a lump under the scar from the biopsy, waited around for another 4 months thinking that it couldn't be anything, I just had a negative biopsy in that same area!  Had to be scar tissue....then it grew more and attached itself to the skin.  Daughter started having mammos at 20 because of my history, she did not feel her lump but primary care doc did and also showed up on mammo.  Exact same size as mine, 1.8 cm.  She had a clear mammo the year before and breast MRI two years before also clear.  No history in our family other than me, now 20 years later her.  Doctors believe there is some mutation other than those they know about that must have started with me.  I worry more because she hasn't had a family yet and wants one....doc said she would be able to go off tamox after two years to try to get pregnant.  Hopefully there will be no problem with infertility after FAC, taxol.  I haven't told her this but I would rather she wouldn't risk pregnancy as she is very ER/PR+, and would adopt instead....but that is a few years off.  Have to stay in the present!
